Posts are publicly visible by default, but senders can restrict message delivery to only their followers. From 2014 to 2017, Twitter offered a "Buy button" feature, allowing tweets to embed products that could be purchased from within the service. "Something happens on Twitter; celebrities, politicians and journalists talk about it, and it's circulated to a wider audience by Twitter's algorithms; journalists write about the dustup." This can lead to an argument on a Twitter feed looking like a "debate roiling the country... regular people are left with a confused, agitated view of our current political discourse".[559] In a 2018 article in the *Columbia Journalism Review*, Matthew Ingram argued much the same about Twitter's "oversized role" and that it promotes immediacy over newsworthiness.[560] In some cases, inauthentic and provocative tweets were taken up as common opinion in mainstream articles.

From Spring 2007 to 2008, the messages were handled by a Ruby persistent queue server called Starling.[361] Since 2009, implementation has been gradually replaced with software written in Scala.[362] The switch from Ruby to Scala and the JVM has given Twitter a performance boost from 200 to 300 requests per second per host to around 10,000–20,000 requests per second per host. This boost was greater than the 10x improvement that Twitter's engineers envisioned when starting the switch. The continued development of Twitter has also involved a switch from monolithic development of a single app to an architecture where different services are built independently and joined through remote procedure calls.[71]

#### On communication[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

In October 2022, billionaire Elon Musk acquired Twitter for US$44 billion, gaining control of the platform and becoming CEO.[24][25][26][27] Since the acquisition, the platform has been criticized for the spread of misinformation and disinformation,[28][29][30] facilitating an increase in hate speech,[31][32][33] promoting antisemitic conspiracy theories[34][35] and transphobia.[36][37]


Linda Yaccarino succeeded Musk as CEO on June 5, 2023, with Musk remaining as Chairman and CTO.[10][38][39] In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to X and that the bird logo would be retired.[40][41] In October 2023, the company estimated its value at about $19 billion, down about 55% from the purchase price one year earlier.[42] Fidelity at about the same time estimated the value to be down 65% from its purchase price.[43]




## History[edit]


See also: Timeline of Twitter




</fragment>
<fragment>

On September 7, 2011, Twitter announced that it had 100 million active users logging in at least once a month and 50 million active users every day.[307] On March 31, 2014, Twitter announced that there were 255 million monthly active users (MAUs) and 198 million mobile MAUs.[308] In 2013, there were over 100 million users actively using Twitter daily and about 500 million tweets every day,[309] with about 29% of users checking Twitter multiple times a day.[310]
As of Q1 2019[update], Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users. The majority of Twitter users skew to the American political left.[311][312][18]


In 2012, the country with the most active users on Twitter was the United States.[313] A 2016 Pew research poll found that Twitter is used by 24% of all online US adults. It was equally popular with men and women (24% and 25% of online Americans respectively), but more popular with younger (36% of 18–29 year olds) generations.[314]


</fragment>
<fragment>

According to research published in April 2014, around 44% of user accounts have never tweeted.[319] About 22% of Americans say they have ever used Twitter, according to a 2019 Pew Research Center survey.[320] In 2009, Nielsen Online reported that Twitter had a user-retention rate of forty percent. Many people stop using the service after a month; therefore the site may potentially reach only about ten percent of all Internet users.[321] Noting how demographics of Twitter users differ from the average Americans, commentators have cautioned against media narratives that treat Twitter as representative of the population,[322] adding that only 10% of users Tweet actively, and that 90% of Twitter users have Tweeted no more than twice. In 2016, shareholders sued Twitter, alleging it "artificially inflated its stock price by misleading them about user engagement". The company announced on September 20, 2021, that it would pay $809.5 million to settle this class-action lawsuit.[323]

Twitter was unable to identify the source of the influence campaign.[499]

### User engagement on X[edit]


User engagement on X is usually measured by the number of likes, replies and reposts.
A recent study[324] shows that retweets are more likely to contain positive content and address larger audiences using the first-person pronoun "we". Replies, on the other hand, are more likely to contain negative content and address individuals using the second-person pronoun "you" and the third-person pronouns "he" or "she". While influencers with many followers tend to post positive messages, often using the word "love" when addressing larger audiences, users with less followers tend to engage in interpersonal conversations to provoke user engagement.

### Fines[edit]


Twitter, and X, has been fined several times for non-compliance with laws and regulations. On May 25, 2022, Twitter was fined $150 million by the Federal Trade Commission and the United States Department of Justice for collecting users' contact details and using them for targeted advertising.[349][350]


In August 2023, Twitter was fined US$350,000 for failing to meet two deadlines to comply with a U.S. Department of Justice search warrant for the account of former president Donald Trump.[351][352]


In October 2023, X was fined AU$610,500 by Australia's e-Safety Commission for failing to properly disclose information about how it polices child abuse content.[353][354]


As of 2023[update] other fines were being considered.[355][356][357]

**X**,[b] formerly called **Twitter**,[c] is an online social media and social networking service operated by the American company X Corp., the successor of Twitter, Inc. On X, registered users can post text, images and videos.[13] Users can also "like", repost, quote repost, comment on posts, direct message, video and audio call, bookmark, join lists and communities, and join public *Spaces* with other registered users. Approved contributors can also leave *Community Notes* to add context to posts by other registered users. Posting information to the site is often referred to as *tweeting*, *retweeting* and *quote tweeting*. Although the service was renamed to "X", its primary website address remains twitter.com as of November 2023[update], with the x.com domain name redirecting to that address.

Posts are publicly visible by default, but senders can restrict message delivery to only their followers. Users can mute users they do not wish to interact with, block accounts from viewing their posts, and remove accounts from their followers list.[176][177][178] Users can post via the Twitter website, compatible external applications (such as for smartphones), or by Short Message Service (SMS) available in certain countries.[179] Users may subscribe to other users' posts—this is known as "following" and subscribers are known as "followers"[180] or "tweeps", a portmanteau of Twitter and peeps.[181] Individual posts can be forwarded by other users to their own feed, a process known as a "repost". In 2015, Twitter launched "quote tweet" (originally called "retweet with comment"),[182] a feature that allows users to add a comment to their post, imbedding one post in the other.[183] Users can also "like" (formerly "favorite") individual tweets.[184]

Individual tweets are registered under unique IDs called snowflakes, and geolocation data is added using 'Rockdove'. The URL shortener *t.co* then checks for a spam link and shortens the URL. Next, the tweets are stored in a MySQL database using Gizzard, and the user receives an acknowledgement that the tweets were sent. Tweets are then sent to search engines via the Firehose API. The process is managed by FlockDB and takes an average of 350 ms.[358]


On August 16, 2013, Raffi Krikorian, Twitter's vice president of platform engineering, shared in a blog post that the company's infrastructure handled almost 143,000 tweets per second during that week, setting a new record. Krikorian explained that Twitter achieved this record by blending its homegrown and open source technologies.[71][363]

Twitter introduced the first major redesign of its user interface in September 2010, adopting a dual-pane layout with a navigation bar along the top of the screen, and an increased focus on the inline embedding of multimedia content. From Spring 2007 to 2008, the messages were handled by a Ruby persistent queue server called Starling.[361] Since 2009, implementation has been gradually replaced with software written in Scala.[362] The switch from Ruby to Scala and the JVM has given Twitter a performance boost from 200 to 300 requests per second per host to around 10,000–20,000 requests per second per host. The continued development of Twitter has also involved a switch from monolithic development of a single app to an architecture where different services are built independently and joined through remote procedure calls.[71]
